issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description: In linux, setnetgrent returns 0 in linux when something wrong is happen, such as out of memory, unknown group, unavailable service, etc. So errorMessage should be set and exception should be thrown
fields.summary: when setnetgrent returns 0 in linux, exception should be thrown

comments.body: [~jlowe] please help review, thanks!
This code change covers more than Linux.  We need to verify it on Solaris/Illumos at a minimum.
[~aw] thanks for review. Uploaded .2 patch which will only cover Linux.
Is throwing an exception really the correct thing to do when a netgroup doesn't exist?  That seems particularly drastic.

This message was automatically generated.

[~aw] thanks for providing opinion. But I still think it's reasonable to thrown an exception because when setnetgrent returns 0 in linux it's not saying the netgroup is empty, but it's actually saying the passed netgroup name is invalid (misconfigured) or if any error occurred.

[~jlowe] thanks for review! Actually after test .2 I found out that it didn't use the THROW macro right. Uploaded .3 patch with right usage of THROW and also change some misleading naming in the c file. I test that the .3 patch throw the right exception and also get logged correctly.  Below is log I get for the test. {code}  Error getting users for netgroup @lasVegas: no netgroup of this name is known or some other error occurred{code}

This message was automatically generated.

Latest patch looks good, at least from the Linux perspective.  Can anyone comment on the other architectures that are returning a value from setnetgrent?  Seems to me that we would want to report an error for the other architectures that are returning an error, otherwise we are silently _not_ loading anything for the netgroup on those platforms.  As I mentioned above, the only difference in practice is whether we log a message when this occurs or not, so I think we should remove the __linux__ check.  Thoughts?
[~jlowe], thanks for review and valuable feedback! But for architecture of Solaris/Illumos, setnetgrent return 0 upon success. So should we limit the scope of fix of this patch only to linux?

bq. But for architecture of Solaris/Illumos, setnetgrent return 0 upon success.
Argh, looks like that is the case.  So helpful that the two architectures decided to do the exact opposite on the return value.

I'm +1 for the .3 patch then, since at least Linux will log something when an error occurs.  Will commit this tomorrow if there are no objections.

bq.  So helpful that the two architectures decided to do the exact opposite on the return value.

Given netgroup was in Sun operating systems since before Linux even existed....

Thanks to Chang for the contribution and to Allen for additional review!  I committed this to trunk, branch-2, and branch-2.7.
